author: 16leiba.bsky.social

author: garyinscotland.bsky.social

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
I may be wrong in this ‚Äì it‚Äôs a story built on gaps rather than hard facts. But they‚Äôre gaps that would likely not be there if facts weren‚Äôt going to follow.

And maybe, just maybe, we can bring the story of HS2 to a real ending.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
Every time someone wants to suggest better trains in Manchester, the rejoinder is ‚Äòwhat about HS2‚Äô. Every WCML upgrade likewise.

This way, we at least know what to plan around, even if we don‚Äôt see it until the 2040s.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text: And this is a good thing, even if you hate HS2. Because we‚Äôre learning the hard way that it‚Äôs much easier to cancel HS2 than exorcise it.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
I suspect this will be a promise to keep the alignment, but not build any actual track. Probably hold a cost review, and maybe even rebrand the whole northern section as something other than ‚ÄòHS2‚Äô. 

But you‚Äôll get your train line to Manchester. Eventually

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
Before you get your hopes up, though; don‚Äôt expect this to mean a new railway any time soon.

First, HS2 is going through a big, painful reset right now. Changing the scope would be profoundly unhelpful

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
So to recap
- Government is obliged to take a stance 
- Government has just endorsed the most complicated unbuilt piece of HS2 
- Government seems to have left a big HS2-sized patch of fog in its spending plans, for announcement this week

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text: To figure out which is true, this paragraph is rather helpful. As is a DfT budget line with a sudden ¬£2.3bn jump in ‚Äònon-HS2‚Äô capital spending next year.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
It says government will spend this much on HS2 _from Birmingham to London_. That has two potential implications:

1) There will be no spending on any other part of HS2, and it‚Äôs permanently cancelled
2) There _will_ be spending on other parts of HS2, but under a different heading.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
And government has been very careful not to say anything about that track. But, as of this week, it will be obliged to. 

That‚Äôs because it has nearly ¬£500m of land compulsorily purchased to get HS2 to Manchester.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
So this means that there‚Äôs now a government backed plan to build a new railway into Manchester on the HS2 alignment. 

This is, by some margin, the trickiest bit left of HS2. It means there are plans to build every HS2 station, just not the track to join them.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
But I thought the last government cancelled HS2 to Manchester? And the new one has said nothing about it?

Yes indeed. But there‚Äôs still a Bill in Parliament, courtesy of the last Tory government. Go read the substack to learn why.

author: roadscholar.bsky.social
text:
Has government just quietly told us that it‚Äôs building HS2? 

I‚Äôd better explain.

text: Today‚Äôs rail announcement through to 2034-35 apparently responds to an estimate of loss from HS2 that has already been rendered obsolete by the much larger losses that will be incurred by the end of this current decade.

author: willhaycardiff.bsky.social
text:
So what does this mean?

Basically over the course of the next four years, Wales will lose more than ¬£100 million in capital funding every year because of HS2‚Äôs designation as an England and Wales project, and the cumulative loss will continue to grow significantly at future Spending Reviews.

author: willhaycardiff.bsky.social
text: If we apply that methodology to the Department for Transport settlement announced today, the WGC estimate that the total loss from HS2 between 2016-17 and 2029-30 now stands at approximately ¬£845 million.

author: willhaycardiff.bsky.social
text: In February 2025, the Welsh Government estimated that the loss in consequentials from HS2 being classified as an England and Wales project (rather than an England-only project) was ¬£431 million, from 2016-17 up to and including 2025-26

author: willhaycardiff.bsky.social
text:
They added:
"Any suggestion that this funding in any way compensates Wales for the loss incurred from HS2 is obviously unsustainable. It does not substantially change the overall picture of underfunding of Welsh rail infrastructure."

Borrowing to finish HS2 will increase Britain's productivity. So will investing in city connectivity. We should do both.

So, close but not quite.

author: dailyherald.bsky.social
text:
Sizewell C produces ~50m¬≥ high-level waste/year; SMRs less. Emissions ~5g CO‚ÇÇ/kWh vs gas ~450g, oil ~650g. Radiation near background levels outside plants. Decommissioning costs ~¬£40‚Äì50m/year per plant, spread over decades for safe dismantling and waste management.

They are safe and clean.

author: dailyherald.bsky.social
text:
Sizewell C and SMRs will generate little waste or radiation, and they are tightly regulated. 

Under Cameron and May nuclear power stations closed while no new ones were opened. This made the UK less energy independent and increased energy prices, while increasing fossil fuel emissions.

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
To recover the ¬£40B build cost over the 60 year life of Sizewell C will require about ¬£90/MWh of electricity generated. Add ¬£50 and you're looking at ¬£140/MWh. 

Today, eholesale prices are around ¬£85/MWh and are expected to fall as gas is pushed off the grid by new wind and solar power.
9/

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
Sizewell C will be paid for in part through the RAB payments but mostly through selling electricity on the open market.

We know from the French nuclear regulator that existing French reactors cost ¬£50/MWh for fuel, operations and maintenance. (The construction costs have been paid off.)
8/

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
When Hinkley Point C reached final investment decision (FID) in 2016, where Sizewell C is now, it was projected to cost ¬£25B and be ready in 2025. Instead it's costing ¬£45B and won't be ready until 2032 (2025 ¬£).
6/

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
Miliband believes that the ¬£17.8B public investment will cover the majority of the cost of Sizewell C because he thinks it will cost ¬£35B or less to build.

Everyone in the industry thinks it will be ¬£40B or more, similar to the ¬£45B cost of Hinkley Point C (all 2025 prices) 
5/

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
late and over the initial budget, meaning the lenders have to hand over far more money (80% more in the case of Hinkley Point C, Sizewell C's predecessor) than originally expected if they actually want something at the end of the ordeal.

This mechanism is called "RAB"
4/

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
During the decade-plus construction period, Sizewell C and its investors will receive money taken from bill-payers to give them cashflow. This is ostensibly to lower the interest rate charged by banks and pension funds lending the money from the very high levels charged on nuclear as it's always 
3/

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
What has Miliband announced today?

Another ¬£14.2B of government borrowing will be made available to Sizewell C Company, the ~90% government-owned (remainder belonging to French state-owned EDF) building Sizewell C.

This takes total UK taxpayer liability so far to ¬£17.8B 
2/

author: dangrey.bsky.social
text:
Miliband has decided that Sizewell C will be majority public-funded with private investment only a minority.

He claims it will be operating in the "mid 2030s".

author: gordonsegar.bsky.social
text: Just a reminder that Sizewell C will increase electricity prices by around 2p per kWh when it goes online some time in the 2030s. The reason is under Regulated Asset Base (RAB) model introduced in 2022, the investment cost is paid back over the expected 60 year operating lifespan.

author: martinmcgrath.bsky.social
text:
Sizewell C will not be producing electricity in a decade *and* the entire ¬£14bn investment mentioned here won't even wet it's feet

Hinckley C might, optimistically, start generating in 2031 - 18 years after go-ahead - with costs at ¬£45bn+

This is fantasy electricity.
www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/c3...

My 2019 post arguing that UK govt should take a stake in building an EPR at Sizewell C, & begin an SMR program

author: alyb.bsky.social
text: Sizewell C - what an utter waste of money and right on the coast. Have they anticipated global sea levels rising not just for the operation period but for the poor sods who are going to have to clean it up with sub aqua gear on! FFS Labour have learned nothing. EDF shame on you.
